I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   During  the  2011  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide capacity 
development technical assistance (TA) for Strengthening the Stress Testing Capacity of the 
Banking System. After consultations with the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) 
and other stakeholders from 5–7 November 2012, a TA fact-finding mission from 28–30 January 
2013 agreed with the government on the objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, 
costs, and terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  In the context of following a moderately loose monetary policy, the PRC’s banking 
institutions increased credit extension in 2009 and 2010 after the 2008 global financial crisis. 
However, the annual growth rate of total assets was modest at 18.0% in 2012, after peaking at 
25.9% in 2009. The other three key ratios for commercial banks also improved—nonperforming 
loans registered at 1.0% in 2012, capital adequacy at 13.3%, and return on equity at 19.9%, 
compared with 2.4%, 12.2%, 17.5%, respectively in 2010. Many regard the PRC banking sector 
as stable despite the fallout of the global financial crisis. This can primarily be attributed to the 
CBRC and the People’s Bank of China (PBC), which instituted stronger risk-based supervision 
and effective monetary policies to mitigate and prevent, to the extent possible, the adverse 
impact of the global financial crisis on the PRC’s banking sector.2   
 
3.  Despite the positive assessment of the PRC’s banking sector, some areas of concern 
have  been  noted.  They  include  an  increasing  nonperforming  loan  ratio  in  export-oriented 
eastern coastal provinces and potential risks as a result of the global economic slowdown; 
potential risks attributable to the rapid growth of real estate loans, local-government-financing 
platform loans, shadow banking system credit flows, and off-balance sheet exposures; and, in 
the long term, adverse impacts of financial reforms, especially further liberalization of interest 
rates on commercial banks and the opening-up of the banking sector. 
 
4.  The  PRC’s  banking  sector  needs  to  rise  to  critical  challenges.  Some  fundamental 
systems and mechanisms for promoting banking system stability have yet to be put in place in 
terms  of  market  discipline,  innovation,  cross-sector  operations,  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprise and rural financing, micro- and macroprudential regulation, deposit insurance, and 
failed bank resolution.3 However, progress is being made in operationalizing critical measures in 
the sector's financial regulation system to support financial stability. The CBRC has introduced, 
among other things, a national capital regulatory framework along with Basel II and III, dynamic 
provisioning requirements, and a leverage ratio. PBC, on the other hand, established a system 
for monitoring and assessing regional financial stability. It undertakes extensive monitoring of 
the inherent risks in the financial industry, and pays particular attention to the cross-border 
contagion risk from overseas financial institutions.  
 
5.  Having  issued  the  new  capital  regulatory  framework in  2012,  the  CBRC  aims  to 
implement Basel II and III requirements at the same time for all commercial banks from January 
2013,  and pillar  II  of  the  new  framework  requires  stress  testing.  Stress  testing  involves 
estimating financial and other impacts from hypothetical changes in the risk environment and is

an important tool for policymakers and banks to identify unexpected adverse outcomes across a 
range of risk factors, including credit, market, and liquidity risks. It plays a particularly important 
role  in  providing  forward-looking  assessments  of  risk,  supporting  internal  and  external 
communications, and facilitating the development of risk mitigation or contingency plans for 
stressed conditions.4 The global financial crisis has significantly increased the focus on stress 
testing.  Financial  institutions  and  their  prudential  regulators  have  been  undertaking  stress 
testing as part of their normal risk management processes.5 The CBRC has issued various 
guidelines requiring commercial banks to conduct stress tests and provided necessary guidance, 
including  a  Guidance  on  Commercial  Banks’  Stress  Testing  (2007).  The  CBRC  and  PBC 
conducted  a  stress  testing  exercise  covering  17  major  commercial  banks,  as  part  of  the 
International  Monetary  Fund/World  Bank  Financial  Sector  Assessment  Program  in  2011.6 
Building on this experience, the CBRC is pursuing advanced stress testing techniques and 
application for itself as well as commercial banks. Strengthening the capacity for stress testing 
is included in the CBRC’s 22 key tasks for 2013.  
 
6.  The  PRC’s  12th  five-year  plan7 for  financial  sector  development  and  reform8 also 
emphasized the importance of strengthening bank risk management. As part of the provision of 
knowledge solutions committed to in the country partnership strategy, 2011–2015, the TA will 
strengthen the CBRC’s institutional capacity for stress testing, enabling it to better recognize the 
weaknesses in the banking industry and to maintain a stable banking system.9 A stable banking 
system is the fundamental element of innovative financing solutions and the improvement of 
financial availability in the priority sectors. By placing a higher priority on small and medium-
sized banks’ capacity building, the TA will also contribute to protecting the poor, who are 
vulnerable to financial and economic cycles. It is included in the 2013 indicative assistance 
pipeline for non-lending products and services of the PRC Country Operations Business Plan, 
2012–2014.10 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be a healthier banking system. The attainment of this impact 
will be demonstrated through an increase in the risk-weighted capital adequacy ratio of the 
banking system. The key outcome of the TA will be the stress testing framework used as an 
integral part of forward-looking risk management by commercial banks, as well as for micro and 
macro prudential supervision by the CBRC.  
 
                                                
4 Standards  Implementation  Group  of  the  Basel  Committee  on  Banking  Supervision.  2012.  Peer  Review  of

Supervision. Basel. Other roles include: overcoming limitations of models and historical data, feeding into the

Implementation Group of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision highlights the following common areas of

B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
8.  The TA will assist the CBRC in improving the stress test operational environment and 
strengthening the stress test capacity of the CBRC and commercial banks, and help conduct 
stress tests. An inception workshop will be held with the executing agency, researchers, and 
other key stakeholders to discuss the feasibility and viability of the TA implementation plan. The 
foundation of stress testing will be strengthened and training will be provided. The TA will also 
assist the CBRC to carry out actual stress tests with advanced techniques and apply the results 
to risk management of the banking sector. During implementation, various knowledge products 
will be produced and workshops will be held, as appropriate, to disseminate information to 
stakeholders and discuss the TA’s implementation progress. 
 
9.  The TA’s outputs are a new stress test operational environment, in-depth stress test 
training, and stress tests by the CBRC. 
(i)  New  stress  test  operational  environment.  The  TA  will  help  the  CBRC 
(a) establish a stress testing unit comprising a wide range of senior experts to 
prepare  a  white  paper  and  a  new  Guidance  on  Commercial  Banks’  Stress 
Testing to be adopted by the CBRC and (b) strengthen the databases of the 
CBRC and commercial banks to reflect the recommendations of the International 
Monetary Fund and the World Bank after the stress testing exercise in 2011. 
(ii)  In-depth stress test training. This includes producing technical instructions on 
the  implementation  and  application  of  stress  testing  by  the  CBRC  and 
commercial banks. The TA will provide training sessions of about 3–4 days per 
cycle (5 cycles in total) to accommodate over 400 CBRC regulators, and one 
cycle of training for 40 risk managers of large banks. Small and medium-sized 
bank  managers  will  be  given  special  focus,  but  the  actual  training  will  be 
conducted by trainees of larger banks, with the CBRC’s support.11 The training 
will be designed at different levels of complexity, covering the state-owned and 
joint-stock banks, the city commercial banks, and the rural commercial banks. 
Technical instructions, mainly focusing on commercial banks’ stress testing and 
the CBRC supervisors’ assessment of commercial banks’ stress testing, and 
training materials for both the CBRC and commercial banks (e.g., manual and 
audiovisual materials) will be produced and disseminated. International study 
visits  will  be  organized  to  learn  from  the  experiences  of  other  countries  in 
designing, conducting, and utilizing stress testing. 
(iii)  The China Banking Regulatory Commission’s stress tests. The TA will help 
the CBRC design and conduct stress tests. After developing stress test models, 
the CBRC will conduct a “top-down” stress test for macroprudential regulation 
that relates to certain macroeconomic risk factors,12 and a reverse stress test for 
the PRC banking sector. The TA will prepare a policy brief with recommendations 
for macroprudential regulation. 
 
                                                
11The  comprehensive  training  program  will  include  sessions  for  training  of  trainers.  The  training  will  also 
accommodate practices for stress testing associated with relatively more advanced countries, which were listed by 
the Standards Implementation Group of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision. The proposed training 
modality would be reviewed during TA implementation.  
12 The stress test will include a scenario analysis, which involves changing multiple risk parameters simultaneously. 
This often applies adverse historical or worst-case forecast outcomes to existing financial soundness indicators to 
understand the deterioration or other impact that may result.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The CBRC, the 
executing agency, will finance trainees’ participation, and provide counterpart support in the 
form of counterpart staff, office space, domestic transportation, secretarial assistance, and other 
in-kind  contributions.  The  CBRC  will  also  arrange  meetings  between  the  consultants  and 
relevant agencies and organizations. The value of CBRC contribution is estimated to account 
for 33% of the total TA cost. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The CBRC will be the executing agency. It will form a stress testing unit, which will 
engage the Statistics Department and other departments concerned, and be chaired by the 
director general of the Statistics Department. 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, from 1 June 2013 to 30 November 2014, 
and will require 6.0 person-months of international consulting services, and 22.5 person-months 
of national consulting services (all stress test experts in various subareas) for a total cost of 
$305,000. The  consultants  will  submit to  both the  CBRC  and  ADB (i)  an  inception report 
2 weeks  after  services  start,  (ii)  a  progress  report  at  an  appropriate  stage  during  TA 
implementation, (iii) a draft final report before the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) the final 
report  2  weeks  after  receiving  comments  from  the  CBRC  and  ADB.  All  reports  must  be 
submitted in English and Chinese. The consultants will also deliver the draft new Guidance on 
Commercial  Banks’  Stress  Testing,  technical  instructions  for  stress  testing  and  training 
materials, the CBRC’s stress test report, and, as knowledge papers, a white paper for the above 
guidance and a policy brief. The consultants will be individually engaged in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The CBRC may use an advance payment facility to conduct workshops and 
training.   
 
13.  The CBRC will regularly monitor and report on major project activities, as will ADB 
review missions. Consultants’ reports will be presented at workshops and seminars organized to 
validate findings. Reports will be made available on ADB's website in English and Chinese and 
published in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2011). 
 
IV.  THE RANKING VICE-PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The  Ranking  Vice-President,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, and acting under the authority 
delegated by the Board, has approved the provision of technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the Government of the People’s Republic of China 
for Strengthening the Stress Testing Capacity of the Banking System, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will assist the China Banking Regulatory Commission 
(CBRC) in improving the stress test operational environment, strengthening the stress test 
capacity of the CBRC and commercial banks, and conducting actual stress tests. 
 
2.  The team leader will be responsible for the quality and timely completion of all outputs to 
ensure acceptance of the TA outcome. All consultants will work under the coordination and 
monitoring  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  project  officer,  who  will  ensure 
complementarity and cohesion in their activities in close consultation with the CBRC. The TA 
will require 6.0 person-months of international and 22.5 person-months of national consulting 
inputs and will be completed within 18 months. 
 
3.  The consultants will produce the following reports: (i) an inception report 2 weeks after 
services start, (ii) a white paper outlining recommendations for improving guidance on stress 
testing and a draft new Guidance on Commercial Banks’ Stress Testing to be adopted by the 
CBRC, (iii) a progress report, (iv) technical instructions and training materials (e.g., manual and 
audiovisual materials), and (iv) a draft final report (including stress test results) and a final report 
2 weeks after receiving comments from the CBRC and ADB, and (v) a policy brief outlining 
recommendations on strengthening the stress testing capacity of the banking system. All reports 
must be submitted in English and Chinese, except for the technical instructions and training 
materials.  
            
B.  Consulting Requirements 
 
1.  Senior Stress Test Expert and Team Leader (international, 6.0 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
4.  The expert should have 
(i)  a PhD in related areas or a senior professional title; 
(ii)  over 10 years of experience in bank supervision and the area of stress testing 
within  the  banking  industry,  preferably  with  the  application  of  stress  testing 
results in bank supervision in developed countries; 
(iii)  broad  experience  in  dealing  with  various  scenarios  in  macroeconomic  and 
financial crises; 
(iv)  extensive knowledge of the latest international techniques on stress testing, and 
quantitative and modeling techniques; and 
(v)  strong leadership skills and experience in conducting training. 
 
5.  The expert’s key tasks are to 
(i)  provide overall guidance and supervision to other team members, in coordination 
with the stress testing unit in the CBRC;  
(ii)  establish a historical stress scenario database for the CBRC; 
(iii)  provide input to the CBRC’s new Guidance on Commercial Banks’ Stress Testing 
and the associated white paper;  
(iv)  take  the  lead  in  preparing  the  technical  instructions,  mainly  focusing  on 
commercial  banks’  stress  testing  and  CBRC  supervisors’  assessment  of 
commercial banks’ stress testing;
